title: Why do people say that they can naturally enjoy atonal music? - Quora

response.answer_text: Liking atonality is like liking coffee. When you’re a kid you don’t like it, but you might try some coffee ice cream and think it’s an interesting flavor. Then you’re drinking cafe au laits, then you’re craving black coffee. The equivalent of coffee flavor in my metaphor is excessive modulation and uncertainty in music. The early atonal music of Schoenberg, Webern, and Berg is late-Romanticism’s obsession with chromaticism and modulation taken to its logical extreme. If you already like Wagner’s Prelude from Tristan und Isolde, then you’re ready to try Schoenberg. If you go straight from Mozart, it’s just gonna sound like a mess. The music I’m talking about here isn’t the same as serial music - Schoenberg invented the serial method later, and I’m pretty sure that serial music or twelve-tone music is what you describe as being “justified with a concept or mathematical reasons”. My impression of serial music so far is that the serial method on its own does nothing to make a piece sound unified and not sound like random notes. To write a good serial piece, the composer really needs to put their own effort in.

I’ll approach this from the side of metal. I enjoy atonality because it can express a whole “new range” of emotions and soundscapes. It can add a surprising element, or express darker themes much more clearly and emphatically than tonality and harmonies. This could be likened to why someone would enjoy horror movies (specifically psychological horror) - the thrill of the unknown and horrifying. While it might be justified with a concept, I don’t see anything wrong with that. A lot of tonal music is also built around concepts. Just listen to any normal metal song that tries to evoke negative emotions like fear, rage, and so on, then listen to this, arguably the pioneering album of atonal metal:  You will hear the difference.
